Hello all,
I would like to require help regarding my thought process in developing the following:

A piece of code that would fire once the application has opened and decide on the activity-flow for the user.
In other words, an "Activity Controller" of sorts that, based on parameters given @ runtime, directs the user to the most appropriate activity.

I was thinking of placing such code under Application.onCreate... but I'm conflicted as to whether that's an appropriate solution.

The use-case: the app has a login screen that should be fired for first-time users. But for non-first-time users, the application should load items, do some communication with the server and display the Landing page.
*The big question is*: which code should be responsible to MANAGE all that?

Naturally I would place the logic in the Login screen, determine whether the user is new or not and redirect him as relevant.
BUT, and here's the big BUT, what if tomorrow I would want the Login screen to appear somewhere else? that is, not when the app starts. Then I'd be in trouble, because the the "application-start" logic would be in the said Login screen. In other words - it's a big no-no from a modular stand-point.

Thanks for reading... apologies if I wasn't clear enough.
hum
<@U0UETGCJU> is this a problem you face often?

apologies for not being clear enough <@U0UEQSNMC> .
I am facing this problem right now regarding a specific project. But it can be applied as easily for all applications that I might develop that are complex enough in their start-up logic
so you want a custom activity delegate?

<@U0UETGCJU>: I have the same situation and the way I have it for now is that I have a MainActivity with a MainPresenter and a LoginActivity and a MainFlowActivity. At the end of the MainActivity `onCreate` I fire up presenter.startAppropriateScreen()` and the presenter decides which one to launch (depending if the user is logged in or not). The problem with this is that the user sees an Activity switch at every launch and the MainFlowActivity needs to be a single instance.

I plan to change this to start with the MainFlowActivity and in it's `onCreate` decide if the LoginActivity should be launched instead

Of course if you skip the `setContentView(R.layout.main_activity);` then you should not have two launches every time but you will still have the single instance problem when the user taps your app's icon to re-open the app from paused
I will post my whole MainActivity since it's quite small if you want to see exactly what I'm talking about
<@U09T8SFG8|aki> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/aki/F0ZTTKMNH/MainActivity.java|MainActivity>

file.name: MainActivity.java
file.title: MainActivity
file.preview_highlight:
public class MainActivity extends BaseActivity implements MainView {
​
    private MainPresenter presenter;
​
    @Override

text: <@U09T8SFG8> this seems like a good solution. I'm not sure that I quite understand the problem though. You're saying this impacts the user's experience because he can actually FEEL when you redirect him to one of the activities?
also, I don't get the Timber and inject lines :simple_smile:
sorry, I'm quite new to android

The first problem is mitigated by skipping setting the content view, so your activity will be invisible. The second issue is that your MainFlowActivity will be restarted every time your user taps the icon of your app in his launcher because that action will always launch the launcher activity which is the MainActivity. Don't worry about Timber and Dagger and the inject annotation, this is for logging and dependency injection you can act as if they are not there at all
<@U0UEQSNMC>: I guess so. not quite sure all of what that entails though
<@U09T8SFG8> Oh, I get it now. Well then the first solution that comes to mind is a quick splash screen instead perhaps?
Or do you have a better idea?
<@U0UETGCJU>: I removed dagger and Timber to make it simpler
Much appreciated
How would the splash screen work?

I meant that it would be set as the default view for setContent of the launcher activity... then, once the run-time code has decided which activity to launch, you initiate it. If I understand the situation correctly, whenever the user would launch the app then he'd get the splash screen and won't notice the new-activity-redirection
You don't need the splash screen at all, the MainActivity won't be shown if you skip the setContentView
yeah, that much is understood. but then your problem is what the user sees when he launches the application, specifically the move to a new activity... correct?
He will either see the LoginActivity or the MainFlowActivity, he won't see the MainActivity
after he sees the activity-switch
no?
There will be no Activity switch
apologies aki but you said there would be so I'm a bit baffled
"The problem with this is that the user sees an Activity switch at every launch and the MainFlowActivity needs to be a single instance."

I talked about two different issues, the first one is the switch which then I said
> The first problem is mitigated by skipping setting the content view, so your activity will be invisible
so skip setting the content view and also add the theme `android:theme="@android:style/Theme.Translucent.NoTitleBar.Fullscreen"` to the MainActivity and you will have no switch
the second issue with the single instance is another issue which should not concern you for now
